metadata.case_name: Asa Ram v. District Board of Muzaffarnagar

facts.text: Asa Ram runs certain machines with the aid of power in premises within Jalalabad town area since 1953-54.

Asa Ram did not take out a licence for running machines for 1953-54 as required by bye-law 7 of Muzaffarnagar Factories Bye-laws framed by District Board of Muzaffarnagar under s.174(1)(k) read with s.106 of U.P. District Boards Act.
Asa Ram prosecuted for contravening the bye-laws; admitted running machines with aid of power but contended premises in town area so bye-laws not applicable and no licence necessary.
Trial Magistrate 1st Class, Muzaffarnagar acquitted Asa Ram on February 14, 1955 in Cr. Case No. 132 of 1955, holding bye-laws not applicable to premises in Jalalabad town area.
District Board filed revision, dismissed by Additional District Magistrate Judicial, Muzaffarnagar on July 13, 1955 in Criminal Revision No. 17/18 of 1955, agreeing with Magistrate.

District Board filed revision to Allahabad High Court in Criminal Revision No. 1724 of 1955; Single Judge on May 11, 1956 set aside acquittal and ordered retrial, granting certificate for appeal to Supreme Court.
Jalalabad town area existed since 1953-54; amendment to Town Areas Act in 1934 substituted 'Town Area Committee' for 'Panchayat' throughout.
Rural area under s.3(10) District Boards Act at relevant time excluded municipalities and cantonments but included town areas; amended in 1958 to exclude town areas.

legal_issues.text: Is running of a flour mill etc. by machines with aid of power an offensive trade within s.26(a) of U.P. Town Areas Act?
Does the word 'regulation' used in s.26(a) U.P. Town Areas Act include the power of issuing a licence?
Does s.93(3) of U.P. District Boards Act amount to a divestment of authority of the District Board in favour of the Town Area Committee in town areas?

petitioner_arguments.text: Bye-laws framed by District Board do not apply to premises within Jalalabad town area; no licence necessary; prosecution bad.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.93(3) U.P. District Boards Act and s.26 U.P. Town Areas Act

respondent_arguments.text: Bye-laws apply even in town areas; s.93(3) does not divest District Board power post-1934 amendment substituting 'Committee' for 'Panchayat' without corresponding change in District Boards Act.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.174(1)(k), s.93(3) U.P. District Boards Act; s.26(a) U.P. Town Areas Act

respondent_arguments.text: Regulation includes power to issue licences.

court_reasoning.text: Running machines with aid of power comes within s.26(a) Town Areas Act as offensive trade; co-extensive with s.174(1)(k) District Boards Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Both bodies have power to regulate such trades.

court_reasoning.text: 'Regulation' includes power of issuing licence; District Board framed bye-laws under regulation power, not specific licence provision; distinguishes Mohamad Yasin case as concerning fees, not licensing power.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court misunderstood Mohamad Yasin; Town Area Committee can frame bye-laws requiring licences under s.26(a).

court_reasoning.text: s.93(3) District Boards Act bars District Board from exercising authority vested in Town Area body; 1934 substitution of 'Committee' for 'Panchayat' is formal/translation change, no substance; restriction continues.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Even if new body post-1934, smaller area law prevails over larger area law on conflict principle.

court_reasoning.text: Where two statutes confer concurrent power, later/special (Town Areas Act for smaller area) prevails over earlier/general (District Boards Act for larger area).
court_reasoning.key_observation: English precedents support: later statute repeals earlier pro tanto.

holdings.text: Running machines is offensive trade under s.26(a) Town Areas Act.
s.93(3) divests District Board of power in town areas where authority vested in Town Area Committee; Committee power prevails.

precedents_cited.case_name: Municipal Board, Hathras v. Behrey Narain Dutt
precedents_cited.relevance: Division Bench held regulation includes licensing; High Court disagreed.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mohamad Yasin v. Town Area Committee, Jalalabad
precedents_cited.relevance: Concerned levy of licence fees, not power to issue licences under regulation.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shrimati Hira Devi v. District Board, Shahjahanpur
precedents_cited.relevance: Courts cannot fill legislative lacunae by liberal construction; different circumstances.
Later Act prevails over earlier repugnant Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: Daw, Clerk of the Commissioner of Sewers of the City of London v. Metropolitan Board of Works
precedents_cited.relevance: Later statute prevails where powers conflict; special over general.

statutes_cited.name: U.P. District Boards Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Power to frame bye-laws for regulating offensive trades; bar on exercising authority vested in town area body; definition of rural area.

statutes_cited.name: U.P. Town Areas Act, 1914
statutes_cited.relevance: Committee power to regulate offensive trades/callings; co-extensive with District Board power.

statutes_cited.name: U.P. Municipalities Act, 1916
statutes_cited.relevance: Similar to s.106 District Boards Act on levying fees.

statutes_cited.name: U.P. Village Panchayat Act, 1920
statutes_cited.relevance: Created village panchayats; led to name change in Town Areas Act to avoid confusion.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, holding that District Board bye-laws do not apply in Jalalabad town area due to s.93(3) divesting power in favour of Town Area Committee; High Court order setting aside acquittal reversed.

key_quotes.text: 'Regulation' would include the power of issuing a licence-and very rightly so.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Overrules High Court's view on scope of 'regulation' under s.26(a).

key_quotes.text: The substitution of the word 'committee' for the word 'panchayat' is merely a translation... it makes no difference to the application of s.93(3).
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects technical argument; upholds divestment of District Board power.

key_quotes.text: The law giving power to the body governing the smaller area should prevail over the law giving power to the body governing the larger area.
key_quotes.speaker: court
